title: IS SEAN SPICER IN HOT WATER OR REALLY HOT WATER?
content:
It ’ s hard to imagine that Melissa McCarthy ’ s devastating Sean Spicer impersonation happened merely a week ago , but the S.N.L . appearance kicked off a week of apparent hell for Donald Trump ’ s press secretary . Though sources told ███ that Spicer himself loved the impression , Trump reportedly was infuriated that the sketch comedy show chose a woman to portray the spokesman , and the reports from Spice World grew worse from there : Trump was reportedly unhappy with Spicer ’ s performance , blaming Reince Priebus for hiring him , and ramping up the search for a communications director to unburden Spicer from his dual roles . ( Apparently no one wants the job . )
No one doubts that the White House needs a communications director—it ’ s widely accepted that Spicer ’ s duties as press secretary ( namely , sparring with the press every day ) leave little time for the broad , strategic tasks . But the otherwise reasonable search for a communications director has slowly evolved into a condemnation of Spicer himself . Several sources told Washingtonian that Carl Higbie , a prominent cable news surrogate for Trump during the campaign and the spokesman for the Great America PAC , had interviewed for the position of Press Secretary . Higbie himself seemed to allude to the interviews when contacted by Washingtonian , saying that he spoken with “ a number of people ” over several rounds of interviews for the post , and was “ honored to be even considered for this . ”
Within minutes of the article ’ s publication , however , the White House told CNN ’ s Dylan Byers on record that the story was “ completely false ” and that , according to spokeswoman Sarah Sanders , Higbie “ hasn ’ t interviewed for anything . He spoke to a few people to say he ’ d like to help . That 's it. ” Higbie himself quickly tweeted that he only had casual discussions , “ NO formal interviews . ”
Whatever Higbie ’ s future role is in the White House—that is , if he has any chance at a role in the White House after this flap—it hints to more dramatic backstabbing in the West Wing . Though the White House has stated repeatedly that Trump is happy with Spicer ’ s performance thus far , the numerous anti-Spicer leaks from the West Wing indicates that , at the very least , someone is unimpressed by the former R.N.C . communications director . Earlier on Friday , before the report about Higbie was published , the Associated Press reported that Trump was unhappy that Spicer told the press that Kellyanne Conway was “ counseled ” for her comments promoting Ivanka Trump ’ s clothing line . Shortly afterwards , Conway , herself a White House counselor , tweeted this :
Trump is in Mar-A-Lago this weekend playing golf with Japanese prime minister Shinzo Abe . Given the Spicer headlines , Conway ’ s recent power moves ( including hiring a chief of staff and maneuvering her husband into consideration for Solicitor General ) , and the separate , ongoing tiff between national security advisor Michael Flynn and vice president Mike Pence over Flynn ’ s unauthorized discussions of sanctions with the Russian ambassador , the staff may well spiral into Real Housewives levels of drama by the time the president returns to the White House .
content_original:
It’s hard to imagine that Melissa McCarthy’s devastating Sean Spicer impersonation happened merely a week ago, but the S.N.L. appearance kicked off a week of apparent hell for Donald Trump’s press secretary. Though sources told Vanity Fair that Spicer himself loved the impression, Trump reportedly was infuriated that the sketch comedy show chose a woman to portray the spokesman, and the reports from Spice World grew worse from there: Trump was reportedly unhappy with Spicer’s performance, blaming Reince Priebus for hiring him, and ramping up the search for a communications director to unburden Spicer from his dual roles. (Apparently no one wants the job.)

No one doubts that the White House needs a communications director—it’s widely accepted that Spicer’s duties as press secretary (namely, sparring with the press every day) leave little time for the broad, strategic tasks. But the otherwise reasonable search for a communications director has slowly evolved into a condemnation of Spicer himself. Several sources told Washingtonian that Carl Higbie, a prominent cable news surrogate for Trump during the campaign and the spokesman for the Great America PAC, had interviewed for the position of Press Secretary. Higbie himself seemed to allude to the interviews when contacted by Washingtonian, saying that he spoken with “a number of people” over several rounds of interviews for the post, and was “honored to be even considered for this.”

Within minutes of the article’s publication, however, the White House told CNN’s Dylan Byers on record that the story was “completely false” and that, according to spokeswoman Sarah Sanders, Higbie “hasn’t interviewed for anything. He spoke to a few people to say he’d like to help. That's it.” Higbie himself quickly tweeted that he only had casual discussions, “NO formal interviews.”

Whatever Higbie’s future role is in the White House—that is, if he has any chance at a role in the White House after this flap—it hints to more dramatic backstabbing in the West Wing. Though the White House has stated repeatedly that Trump is happy with Spicer’s performance thus far, the numerous anti-Spicer leaks from the West Wing indicates that, at the very least, someone is unimpressed by the former R.N.C. communications director. Earlier on Friday, before the report about Higbie was published, the Associated Press reported that Trump was unhappy that Spicer told the press that Kellyanne Conway was “counseled” for her comments promoting Ivanka Trump’s clothing line. Shortly afterwards, Conway, herself a White House counselor, tweeted this:

Trump is in Mar-A-Lago this weekend playing golf with Japanese prime minister Shinzo Abe. Given the Spicer headlines, Conway’s recent power moves (including hiring a chief of staff and maneuvering her husband into consideration for Solicitor General), and the separate, ongoing tiff between national security advisor Michael Flynn and vice president Mike Pence over Flynn’s unauthorized discussions of sanctions with the Russian ambassador, the staff may well spiral into Real Housewives levels of drama by the time the president returns to the White House.
